[start of motion plan]
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the robot is gripping a human wrist. The wrist is slightly dislocated. The table is a flat, presumably rigid surface.
The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The origin of the wrist frame is located at the robot's gripper on the human wrist.
The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward motion in the world. Moving the wrist in the positive Z direction will move the wrist upwards relative to the gripper. Moving the wrist in the negative Z direction will move the wrist downwards relative to the gripper.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move downwards slightly to align the dislocated joint, which translates to negative Z motion.
The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion to the right in the world. Moving the wrist in the positive X direction will move the wrist to the right relative to the gripper. Moving the wrist in the negative X direction will move the wrist to the left relative to the gripper.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move slightly to the left, which translates to negative X motion.
The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion into the image in the world. Moving the wrist in the positive Y direction will move the wrist into the image relative to the gripper. Moving the wrist in the negative Y direction will move the wrist out of the image relative to the gripper.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move slightly outward the image, which translates to negative Y motion.
To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved slightly down, to the left, and outward from the image to set the dislocated wrist back in place.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: The human arm is made of bone, muscle, and skin. The mass of the forearm and hand is estimated to be 2kg. The static friction coefficient between the robot gripper and human skin is estimated to be 0.6. The wrist joint is assumed to have slight stiffness.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity acts on the arm. The arm is resting on the table, so there is a normal force from the table acting on the arm. There may be slight damping from surrounding tissue.
- The relevant object is the human forearm/hand has mass 2 kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of 0.6.
- The surface of interaction is the skin of the forearm and robot gripper has a static friction coefficient of 0.6 with the object.
- Contact Types: Pinch grasp by the robot gripper. Maintaining surface contact of the forearm with the table.
- Motion Type: Small linear movements to relocate the dislocated wrist joint.
- Contact Considerations: The robot must maintain a stable grasp on the wrist while applying the relocation motion. Additional forces may be required to prevent the wrist from slipping out of the gripper.
- Motion along axes: The robot exerts motion in a "linear" fashion along the wrist's [x, y, z] axes and a possible small rotational motion along the wrist's [rx, ry, rz] axes.
- Task duration: The task motion is estimated to take 2 seconds.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Mass of forearm and hand = 2 kg. Static friction coefficient = 0.6. Acceleration due to gravity = 9.81 m/s^2.
- Relevant equations: F = ma (Newton's second law). F_friction = mu * F_normal.
- Relevant assumptions: The arm is rigid. The table is flat and rigid. The motion is slow and controlled.
- Computations: The force due to gravity acting on the forearm and hand is F_gravity = mg = 2 kg * 9.81 m/s^2 = 19.62 N. The normal force from the table is equal to the force due to gravity. The force required to overcome static friction is F_friction = mu * F_normal = 0.6 * 19.62 N = 11.77 N.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 2 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.6 along the surface: The robot needs to apply a force to overcome static friction and move the wrist.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon moving the wrist slightly to the left, the object in the image must exert negative force along the X-axis with magnitude 2 N.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon moving the wrist slightly outwards, the object in the image must exert negative force along the Y-axis with magnitude 1 N.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon moving the wrist downwards, the object in the image must exert negative force along the Z-axis with magnitude 1 N.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon no rotational motion, the object in the image must exert no torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0 N-m.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon no rotational motion, the object in the image must exert no torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0 N-m.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon no rotational motion, the object in the image must exert no torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0 N-m.
Grasping force: The grasping force should be sufficient to maintain a secure grip without causing discomfort or injury. Thus 10 to 20 N .

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The human forearm/hand has a mass of 2 kg. The static friction coefficient between the robot gripper and human skin is 0.6."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Slight movement to the left, outward, and downwards to relocate the dislocated wrist joint."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [-0.005, -0.003, -0.003]
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [-2, -1, -1, 0, 0, 0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 15
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 2
```

[end of motion plan]

The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
